The Ugly Truth about Covid-19 Situation in Indonesia

This article aims to do a fact checking of some officials’ controversial statements related to Covid-19 situation in Indonesia.

Dewi Lestari Amaliah true
08-31-2020

Introduction

The statements from officials, experts, and leaders matter during an ongoing crisis, in this case, is Covid-19. It is because the messages that being told would determine people’s expectation, fear, and reactions to the pandemic (Westman 2020). The problem is that not all the information regarding the crisis is true. The World Health Organization (WHO) even stated that the urgent measure to tackle the “coronavirus infodemic”, the term for Covid-19 misinformation, should be taken immediately (Ghebreyesus and Ng 2020). This infodemic would lead to public confusion about what information and which source to trust (Ali and Kurasawa 2020).

One of the examples of the communication problem was shown by the U.S. government. While the U.S. Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) stated that the situation would change quickly and the future is still unknown, President Trump claimed a convincing timeline of vaccine development (Westman 2020).

Indonesia, the most populous country in South East Asia, also experiences a similar problem. Since the beginning of the emergence of Covid-19 in this country, the officials has made several controversial statements shown Figure 1. One of the reasons why these statements are considered controversial is because as per 28th August 2020, the country is reported has the highest death toll in the region, with 7.169 deaths, more than doubled the second place, Philippines, with 3.325 deaths (Center For Strategic & International Studies 2020). In addition, it is feared that these positive statements will make the public less careful about the virus. Especially now that Indonesia has applied the “New Normal” policy that intended reopening of all the social and economic sectors’ followed with strict hygiene and health protocol (Kusumaningdiyah 2020).

Therefore, this article aims to do fact checking of these controversial claims using multiple data sources related to Covid-19.

Figure 1: The timeline of controversial statement made by the government of Indonesia

Data Description

This article is utilized the compiled dataset from tidycovid19 R package (Gassen 2020). This package comprises of Covid-19 related data from various source at the country-day level. Initially, there are 207 countries covered in this dataset, but for this article purpose, I used only Indonesia data start from the first case was recorded. Besides, to achieve the aim of this article, I mainly used the confirmed, fatality, and recovered cases data, which are compiled from John Hopkins University Center for System Science and Engineering (JHU CSSE) (John Hopkins University Center for System Science and Engineering 2020); the lockdown measure data from ACAPS (ACAPS 2020); the testing data from Our World in Data (Our World in Data 2020); and the population data from the World Bank (World Bank 2020).

That being said, I also provided most of the variables in the compiled data in the package in Table 1. Note that I excluded the region variable (East Asia and Pacific), the income (upper middle income), and the time stamp variable (because it is the same with date variable) from the display.


Table 1. The raw data of Covid-19 in Indonesia

The definition of each variable can be seen here.

Table 1: Variable definition of Covid-19 dataset
Variable Name Source Definition
iso3c NA ISO3c country code as defined by ISO 3166-1 alpha-3
country NA Country name
date NA Calendar date
confirmed jhu_ccse Confirmed Covid-19 cases as reported by JHU CSSE (accumulated)
deaths jhu_ccse Covid-19-related deaths as reported by JHU CSSE (accumulated)
recovered jhu_ccse Covid-19 recoveries as reported by JHU CSSE (accumulated)
ecdc_cases ecdc_covid19 Covid-19 cases as reported by ECDC (accumulated)
ecdc_deaths ecdc_covid19 Covid-19-related deaths as reported by ECDC (accumulated)
total_tests owid_testing Accumulated test counts as reported by Our World in Data
tests_units owid_testing Definition of what constitutes a ‘test’
soc_dist acaps_npi Number of social distancing measures reported up to date by ACAPS, net of lifted restrictions
mov_rest acaps_npi Number of movement restrictions reported up to date by ACAPS, net of lifted restrictions
pub_health acaps_npi Number of public health measures reported up to date by ACAPS, net of lifted restrictions
gov_soc_econ acaps_npi Number of social and economic measures reported up to date by ACAPS, net of lifted restrictions
lockdown acaps_npi Number of lockdown measures reported up to date by ACAPS, net of lifted restrictions
apple_mtr_driving apple_mtr Apple Maps usage for driving directions, as percentage*100 relative to the baseline of Jan 13, 2020
apple_mtr_walking apple_mtr Apple Maps usage for walking directions, as percentage*100 relative to the baseline of Jan 13, 2020
apple_mtr_transit apple_mtr Apple Maps usage for public transit directions, as percentage*100 relative to the baseline of Jan 13, 2020
gcmr_retail_recreation google_cmr Google Community Mobility Reports data for the frequency that people visit retail and recreation places expressed as a percentage*100 change relative to the baseline period Jan 3 - Feb 6, 2020
gcmr_grocery_pharmacy google_cmr Google Community Mobility Reports data for the frequency that people visit grocery stores and pharmacies expressed as a percentage*100 change relative to the baseline period Jan 3 - Feb 6, 2020
gcmr_parks google_cmr Google Community Mobility Reports data for the frequency that people visit parks expressed as a percentage*100 change relative to the baseline period Jan 3 - Feb 6, 2020
gcmr_transit_stations google_cmr Google Community Mobility Reports data for the frequency that people visit transit stations expressed as a percentage*100 change relative to the baseline period Jan 3 - Feb 6, 2020
gcmr_workplaces google_cmr Google Community Mobility Reports data for the frequency that people visit workplaces expressed as a percentage*100 change relative to the baseline period Jan 3 - Feb 6, 2020
gcmr_residential google_cmr Google Community Mobility Reports data for the frequency that people visit residential places expressed as a percentage*100 change relative to the baseline period Jan 3 - Feb 6, 2020
gtrends_score google_trends Google search volume for the term ‘coronavirus’, relative across time with the country maximum scaled to 100
gtrends_country_score google_trends Country-level Google search volume for the term ‘coronavirus’ over a period starting Jan 1, 2020, relative across countries with the country having the highest search volume scaled to 100 (time-stable)
region wbank Country region as classified by the World Bank (time-stable)
income wbank Country income group as classified by the World Bank (time-stable)
population wbank Country population as reported by the World Bank (original identifier ‘SP.POP.TOTL’, time-stable)
land_area_skm wbank Country land mass in square kilometers as reported by the World Bank (original identifier ‘AG.LND.TOTL.K2’, time-stable)
pop_density wbank Country population density as reported by the World Bank (original identifier ‘EN.POP.DNST’, time-stable)
pop_largest_city wbank Population in the largest metropolian area of the country as reported by the World Bank (original identifier ‘EN.URB.LCTY’, time-stable)
life_expectancy wbank Average life expectancy at birth of country citizens in years as reported by the World Bank (original identifier ‘SP.DYN.LE00.IN’, time-stable)
gdp_capita wbank Country gross domestic product per capita, measured in 2010 US-$ as reported by the World Bank (original identifier ‘NY.GDP.PCAP.KD’, time-stable)
timestamp NA Date and time where data has been collected from authoritative sources

Analysis and Findings

The analysis is performed mainly using the functions in tidyverse (Wickham et al. 2019) package in R (R Core Team 2020). I also used DT (Xie, Cheng, and Tan 2020), kableExtra (Zhu 2019), timevis (Attali and Almende B.V. 2019), plotly (Sievert 2020), gridExtra (Auguie 2017), and formattable (Ren and Russell 2016) packages. Since tidycovid19 only provides cumulative cases, death, recovered, and tests, I wrangled the dataset to obtain the daily number. I also mutated new variables, namely infection rate, positive rate, and testing rate. The definition of those variables is as follows:

  • Infection rate: According to Health Centric Advisors Health Centric Advisors (2017), there are three ways of calculating the infection rate. The formula I used here is the number of infected people divided by the total population multiplied by the constant variable, which is 1,000,000 people, this figure is calculated in a daily level.
  • Positive rate: It is the fraction of tests that have a positive result. The calculation is the number of cumulative confirmed cases divided by the total tests (percentage) (Jr. 2020).
  • Testing Rate : The number of test per 1,000,000 population at daily level.


Limitation

Since the results of the Covid-19 test in Indonesia were not released on the same day, there should be a lag between the number of cases and the number of tests used to calculate the positive rate. However, the length of lag between the test time and the results varies between test locations, making it difficult to determine the right lag. Therefore, in the calculation, the positive rate is based on the cumulative number.

For the lockdown variable in the dataset, that I previously wanted to use, it apparently did not match with the date of “New Normal” policy began in Indonesia. Thus, I ended up not using this data.

In addition, I would not check all of the statements in Figure 1. I would only check the statements that could be answered using this dataset one by one.


Statement 1: Covid-19 spread has gone down, so the “New Normal” scheme could be applied.

This claim was stated by the Coordinating Minister for Maritime Affairs and Investment, Luhut Binsar Pandjaitan, on June, 2nd 2020. He claimed that the decision to reopen the economy and ease the mobility restriction, which is called the “New Normal”, is based on data that the spread of the virus has declined and the number of new cases has gone down to 600 cases per day on average (Afriyadi 2020).

The Fact

There are two main points that I would check in this statement. First, is the declining of the average of new cases per day and the second is the declining of the virus spread.

The number of daily case shown in Figure 2 suggests that it was true that the number of cases as of June, 2 2020 was 609, as claimed. Previous days, the number of cases was also in the range of 600s. However, we could not really say that the cases was declining as until this statement was made, June 2 2020, the trend was positive.

Regarding the spreading of the virus, the Minister did not say its definition. Thus, I would assume that it is the infection rate, since the spread is supposed to be regarding the number of people who are likely to get infected by the virus. The infection rate shown in Figure 2 suggests that the spread of the virus was not declining. It was true that the infection rate had decreased at the end of May, compared to the third week of May, but again, the trend line shows that the spread of the virus was still increasing.

The government, should have seen the bigger picture, instead of the spike shown in only a short time period. Hence, we could argue that this claim is busted.

Figure 2: Daily confirmed cases and infection rate of Covid-19 in Indonesia from 2020-03-2 until 2020-06-02

Despite this positive trend, Indonesian government has applied the “New Normal” scheme started from 5th June 2020 (Widodo 2020). Therefore, I was curious about how the statistics changed after this scheme put in. I used median value as the summary statistics because the distribution of the indicators, which are the daily cases, daily fatality, daily recovered, daily testing, infection rate, testing rate, and positive rate are mostly skewed, especially before “New Normal” phase. According The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) (Australian Bureau of Statistics 2013), the median is more robust to skewed data and is sometimes the favorable measure of central tendency when the distribution is asymmetric.

Expand here to see the distribution.


Table 2. Covid-19 indicators before and after “New Normal” policy in Indonesia

Indicator Before New Normal After New Normal
Median of daily confirmed cases 297.000 1693
Median of daily fatality 15.000 66
Median of daily recovered 46.000 1474
Median of daily people tested 3092.000 12168.5
Median of daily infection rate 1.097 6.256
Median of daily testing rate 11.425 44.964
Median of cumulative positive rate 14.415 12.279

All indicators in Table 2. show an increase after the “New Normal” policy was implemented. If we look at the number of confirmed cases and the infection rate, we will conclude that after the “New Normal”, there has been a drastic increase in Covid-19 cases in Indonesia by about five times. Likewise with the death toll and recovery cases, the number was increasing because the number of cases was increasing.

In fact, this does not necessarily explain the true condition because the number of cases is greatly influenced by the number of people tested. If we look at the number of people tested, there was an increase after the “New Normal” period, even though the rate is only 43 people per 1,000,000 population per day. Hence, increasing cases makes sense.

Furthermore, if we look at a positive rate, we can see that looking at the number of positive cases only is not enough. In fact, there was a decrease in positive rates after the “New Normal”. However, bear in mind that the positive rate here is cumulative figure. In addition, speaking of positive rate and “New Normal”, the WHO recommended that the positive rate from a comprehensive testing program should be at or below 5 percent for at least 14 days to ease the restriction and resume the economic and social activity (Jr. 2020). How about Indonesia? Figure 3 shows the answer that Indonesia did not follow the WHO reccommendation because the positive rate was still above 10 percent when the “New Normal” began.


Statement 2: The COVID-19 positive rate has gone down and recovery rate has improved greatly to almost 66%

This contend was stated also by the Coordinating Minister for Maritime Affairs and Investment on August, 14th 2020 (Rosana 2020). Luhut Claimed that the handling of Covid-19, shown by the declining positive rate, has improved. Moreover, the recovery rate is nearly 66 percent.

The Fact

Figure 3 shows that the positive rate has decreased when compared to the start of the pandemic in the country. However, in this figure, we can see that there is a slight inverted curve which indicates that the positive rate is increasing again.

Regarding 66 percent recovery claims, I tried to divide the recovered cases by the confirmed cases on that date and got a result of 66.32 percent. This means that the claim is true.

But wait, is this good news? According to the health experts, using the recovery rate as an indicator to assess the performance of handling Covid-19 is not ideal. This is because first, the recovery rate is calculated by dividing the number of discharged patients with total Covid-19 patients. However, those who are hospitalized can either recover or die, so they cannot be included in the calculation (Devulapalli 2020). Secondly, 99% of people infected with COVID recovers, so the number of recovery rate is not really useful (Warrier 2020).

Figure 3: The positivity rate of Covid-19 in Indonesia


Statement 3: There will not be a second wave of COVID-19 outbreak in Indonesia

The Coordinating Minister for Maritime Affairs and Investment did seem to like to preach “good news”. On 13 August 2020, he claimed that Indonesia would not experience the second wave of Covid-19 (Thomas 2020).

The Fact

The fact of this claim is pretty straight forward. It is true. According to Dr.Anthony Fauci, the director of the U.S. National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, the second wave happens if the number of confirmed cases goes up and then comes back down to reach low single digits (Stieg 2020). The example of this case is New Zealand, who had 24 days streak of zeros case before getting the new cases again. Hence, how could Indonesia experience the second wave, if the first wave has not yet reached its peak?

Figure 4: The number of confirmed cases daily in Indonesia


Statement 4: COVID-19 in Indonesia is now under control

Now, you could guess who made the statement. Yes, it is correct. This statement was, again, told by the Minister for Maritime Affairs and Investment on 19 August 2020.

The Fact

The fact is this claim is might be incorrect, at least according to the WHO criteria. According to the WHO in May, one of the indicator that the epidemic is under control is that the positive rate is less than 5 percent (Our World in Data 2020). As per date of this statement, the positive rate in Indonesia is 13.22 percent.

Conclusion

Three out of four of Luhut’s claims, which were checked with data from various sources, were correct, in numerical terms. However, if we look at the bigger picture and the context, these claims were actually busted. For example, if the trend is seen in its entirety since the beginning of the pandemic, the cases and the spread of Covid-19 in Indonesia could not be said as declined. Besides, contextually, the usage of recovered cases as an indicator to claim the success of Covid-19 handling could not be justified.

The ugly truth about the Covid-19 situation in Indonesia is that the cases are still increasing, the testing rates per 1,000,000 population are still small, and the positive rate is still above 5 percent. However, the uglier truth is that the “false positive claims” have been made by the person who should have known better.
